title: Strife looms as MTA approves ‘largest ever’ capital plan
text:
As the MTA is hiring new cops, it is contemplating service cuts along the Utica Avenue bus line, one of the city’s busiest. | Getty Images Strife looms as MTA approves ‘largest ever’ capital plan

As the MTA board approved its "largest ever" five-year capital plan on Wednesday, pegged at $51 billion, the mood was not as celebratory as might be expected.

Union members wore “gentrify my paycheck” shirts and said every MTA board member was a “lackey for a gangster governor.” They said management had “blood” on its hands. They name-checked MTA chairman Pat Foye’s hometown (Port Washington) and his compensation (They inflated it to $400,000. It’s more like $350,000.). They even hinted at a strike.

Story Continued Below

Board members, meanwhile, bemoaned a less-than-transparent planning process, and warned that without more operating funds, no one would be around to drive all the new trains the MTA is buying.

“We’re going to have the most fabulous new signals, the most fabulous new rolling stock, accessibility for all, but it’s going to be running less frequently,” said Andrew Albert, a non-voting board member.

Once it goes into effect in 2021, congestion pricing is expected to add substantial resources to the MTA’s capital budget — which pays for long-term improvements, like new subway cars and signaling systems.

The MTA’s operating budget, on the other hand, remains a hot mess.

The MTA is forecasting deficits of $600 million in 2021, $800 million in 2022 and $1 billion in 2023. Officials hope to slash those deficits by restructuring the state authority, but analysts tend to regard those hopes as overly optimistic. In the meantime, after apparent pressure from Gov. Andrew Cuomo, the MTA has to find room in its operating budget to pay for 500 new police officers.

That will cost $56 million the first year and ramp up to $120 million a year 10 years on, according to an analysis released Wednesday by the nonpartisan Citizens Budget Commission. The MTA contends the cops will partly pay for themselves by cracking down on fare evasion.

“Where have we talked about how that’s going to be budgeted?” asked MTA board member Bob Linn, an appointee of Mayor Bill de Blasio.

As the MTA is hiring new cops, it is contemplating service cuts along the Utica Avenue bus line, one of the city’s busiest.

Meanwhile, the MTA has to hammer out a contract with the Transport Workers Union, which represents subway and bus workers.

To help stabilize the MTA's operating budget, Foye is demanding worker give-backs that those workers seem disinclined to provide.

In an ad the union is running on 1010 WINS, Transport Workers Union Local 100 president Tony Utano says “multimillionaire chairman Pat Foye is outrageously blaming workers for budget gaps.”

Utano goes on to promote an Oct. 30 rally at MTA headquarters.

“Now it’s time for the MTA to hear our voices,” Utano says.
description: The MTA’s operating budget remains a hot mess.
